nor.sentence: Nor was Europe open to the depredations of the northern pirates only.

Nor was this confined to the Cinque Port vessels only; the example and the profits were too stimulating to the restless; and one daring association on the coast of Lincolnshire seized the Isle of Ely, and made it their receptacle for the plunder of all the adjacent countries.

masters.sentence: Masters of all the islands in the Mediterranean, their corsairs insulted the coasts of Italy, and even threatened the destruction of the Eastern empire.

while.sentence: While the King of Sweden and his forces were engaged with their attack upon Olafs centre of battle, Earl Erik adopted a plan which, although seemingly more hopeless, was in the end more successful than any that had yet been attempted by either the Danes or the Swedes.
While the Danes were in full retreat the Swedes hastened forward to renew the attack.

While Alexis was occupied in a war with Patzinaces, on the banks of the Danube, Zachas, a Saracen pirate, scoured the Archipelago, having, with the assistance of an able Smyrniote, constructed a flotilla of forty brigantines, and some light fastrowing boats, manned by adventurers like himself.

While Kolbiorn and others of Olafs stem defenders kept up an incessant battle with their javelins and swords, King Olaf and his archers shot their arrows high in air so that they fell in thick rain upon the Danish decks.

While the vikings were at this work a constant rain of arrows and javelins was showered upon them by King Olaf himself and his marksmen on the poop, and as Erik saw his best men falling he half repented having taken them from the fight.

maritime.sentence: Maritime pursuits had now revived, the improvement of nautical science was progressing rapidly, and the advantages of predatory expeditions, especially when assisted and masked by commerce, led people of family and acquirements to embrace the profession.

pouring.sentence: Pouring hundreds of boats down the Borysthenes, the Russian marauders made four desperate attempts to plunder the city of the Caesars, in less than two centuries, and appear only to have been repulsed by the dreadful effects of the celebrated Greek fire.

england,.sentence: England, in the mean time, had little to do with piracy; nor had she any thing worthy the name of a navy; yet Coeur de Lion had given maritime laws to Europe; her seamen, in point of skill, were esteemed superior to their contemporaries; and King John enacted that those foreign ships which refused to lower their flags to that of Britain should, if taken, be deemed lawful prizes.

,.sentence: , though Hugh de Burgh, the governor of Dover Castle, had defeated a French fleet by casting lime into the eyes of his antagonists, the naval force was impaired to such a degree that the Normans and Bretons were too powerful for the Cinque Ports, and compelled them to seek relief from the other ports of the kingdom.

nay.sentence: Nay more: on the disputes which took place between Henry and his Barons, in 1244, the Cinque Ports, who had shown much indifference to the royal requisitions, openly espoused the cause of the revolted nobles; and, under the orders of Simon de Montfort, burnt Portsmouth.

those.sentence: Those harumscarum expeditions, the Crusades, were perhaps influential in checking piracy, although the rabble that composed the majority of them had as little principle as the worst of the freebooters.

still,.sentence: Still, many of the kings men thought of nothing but going constantly forward, and in their eagerness and daring they seemed to forget that they were not on dry land.

Still, the effect of such incredible numbers of people betaking themselves to foreign countries, advanced civilization, although vast means of forwarding its cause were buried in the East; and those who assert that no benefit actually resulted, cannot deny that at least some evils were thereby removed.

montesquieu.sentence: Montesquieu says, that Europe then required a general shock, to teach her, but the sight of contrasts, the theorems of public economy most conducive to happiness.

loud.sentence: Loud and shrill sounded the war horns from both sides.

sweyns.sentence: Sweyns ship lay under the larboard bow of the Serpent, and Wolf the Red had thrown out grappling hooks, holding her there.
Sweyns men turned their stems towards both bows of the Long Serpent, as she stood much further forward than any others of Olafs ships.

olafs.sentence: Olafs voice sounded loud above the tumult, calling to his chiefs in the bow to leave their station and resist the boarders in the waist.
Olafs archers and spearmen dealt such destruction that the victory for Norway seemed to become more possible with every moment.
Olafs warriors, one and all, raised their shields above their heads and held them there while the rain of shafts pattered upon them with a loud drumming noise that could be heard far across the bay.
Olafs prows were so lofty that they could not be scaled, while the defenders, from their higher stand, had full command over their foes.

thrand.sentence: Thrand Squint Eye and Ogmund Sandy were the first of the Norsemen to fall.

kolbiorn.sentence: Kolbiorn Stallare was very angry at these two having broken the ranks, and he gave the order that none of the Norsemen were to attempt to board the enemys ships without express command.
Kolbiorn was about to repeat the blow when several of the Danes, retreating aft, crowded between him and their king.
Kolbiorn felled two of them and turned to a third.
Kolbiorn vanquished the third viking he had engaged with, while Earl Erik was pressed back and back by Thorfinn the Dashing.

sharp.sentence: Sharp and fierce was the fight at this side, and great was the carnage.

although.sentence: Although they found it impossible to board the Serpent, they nevertheless could assail her crowded decks with arrows and well aimed spears, and the Norsemen fell in great numbers.

time.sentence: Time after time he called to his followers, and led them with a fierce rush down upon the enemys decks, sweeping all before him.

seven.sentence: Seven of King Sweyns vessels did he thus clear; and at last no more came, and for a time he had rest.

calling.sentence: Calling to his shield bearers to make way for him, he pressed through the gap and leapt down upon the deck of Sweyn Forkbeards dragon.

sweyn.sentence: Sweyn drew back, and crying aloud to his men to follow him, turned tail and led them over the bulwarks on to the deck of a ship that was alongside of him.

tired,.sentence: Tired, wounded, and despairing, he owned himself no match for Olaf the Glorious.

vain.sentence: Vain were the Swede kings hopes.

scarcely.sentence: Scarcely had they made half a dozen passes when Olaf Triggvison, with a quick movement of his wrist, struck his opponents sword from his grasp and it fell on the deck.

pick.sentence: Pick up your blade, proud King of the Swedes, and let us see who is the better man, you or I.

guard.sentence: Guard well your head, returned Triggvison, lest I knock off your helmet.

swedish.sentence: Swedish sword blades are good, said Olaf Triggvison, but the swords of the Norsemen are better.

true.sentence: True to the agreement which he and the two allied kings had come to over their dice throwing on the morning of that same fateful day, he had stood apart from the battle while Sweyn had vainly striven to make a prize of the Long Serpent; and during the midday and until the retreat of King Sweyn he had engaged no more in the conflict than to direct his arrows from afar into the thick of Olaf Triggvisons host.

pride.sentence: Pride in his own countryman may have had some share in the forming of this opinion.

her.sentence: Her commander, Thorkel Nefja, had fallen, and the larger number of her men had retreated on board of Olafs ship, driven thither by the vikings of the six vessels that were now ranged close against her.

Her poop and her prow were the only points of her hull that were exposed, and these towered so high above the bulwarks of all other vessels that to attempt to board her was both useless and dangerous.

herein.sentence: Herein lay the secret of Olafs successful defence, the proof of his forethought and wisdom in building the Serpent so much larger and higher than all other vessels in his fleet.

urging.sentence: Urging his rowers to their fullest speed, Erik bore down with his ships upon the extreme of King Olafs right wing.

very.sentence: Very soon the decks of the first longship were completely cleared of defenders.

five.sentence: Five men only of those who had sailed returned with her.
Five of the viking ships lay with their high prows overshadowing the broadside bulwarks, and their men swarmed and clamoured upon the decks from stem to stern, clearing all before them.

leaving.sentence: Leaving his six ships where he had stationed them, Earl Erik now rowed the Iron Ram round to the left wing of Olaf Triggvisons array.

four.sentence: Four of his best longships followed him.

waving.sentence: Waving his sword in mock salute, Earl Erik cried aloud:  Short will be Olafs shrift when Erik boards the Long Serpent!

already.sentence: Already the Short Serpent was greatly crippled.

regardless.sentence: Regardless of his own life, Thorkel fought with savage fury.

chapter.sentence: CHAPTER XXII: THE DEFENCE OF THE LONG SERPENT   The sun was sinking lower and lower to the sea; light clouds were gathering in the western sky.

also.sentence: Also he saw on coming nearer to King Olafs ship that it would be no easy matter to win on board of her; for the Iron Ram was but a third of her length, and her highest bulwarks reached only to a level with the oar holes in the Serpents wales.

small.sentence: Small boats had been put out to pick up the men who had fallen, or been thrust overboard from the ships.

most.sentence: Most of them crossed the gangway to certain death; but many of the kings men also fell, both from wounds and from sheer exhaustion.

company.sentence: Company after company of the vikings clambered on board, for so fully were the kings men occupied in guarding their own lives that they could give little heed to their foes, who seemed to come from every point, not only from the Iron Ram, but also from other ships that were now drawn close in against the Serpents hull.

spears.sentence: Spears and arrows flew in the midst, not aimed at random, but each at its own particular mark, and each carrying death on its keen point.

bersi.sentence: Bersi the Strong replied: Our swords are both dull and broken, lord.
Bersi the Strong encountered the earl hand to hand, their swords clashed, a few blows were exchanged and dexterously guarded; then Bersi fell.

others.sentence: Others saw the blood; but no one knew where the king was wounded.

nevertheless,.sentence: Nevertheless, it was easy to see that the greater loss was on the side of Earl Erik.

wolf.sentence: Wolf the Red, Ogmund Sandy, and Thrand Squinteye had already fallen, and Ketil the Tall and Vikar of Tiundaland had been sent below seriously wounded.

thorfinn.sentence: Thorfinn the Dashing took his place, and while the earl and he were fighting their hardest, Thorstein Oxfoot and Kolbiorn engaged with four of the earls vikings.

thorstein.sentence: Thorstein doubled his fist and struck his opponent on the cheek.
Thorstein then recovered his sword and fought valiantly.

weapons,.sentence: Weapons, and not fists or timber, are meant for men to fight with in battle!

great.sentence: Great is Earl Eriks luck today.

einar.sentence: Einar seized the kings bow and straightway drew it right over the arrowhead, bending it almost double.
Einar saw the vexation in King Olafs face, and when he got a good chance he levelled his aim against Earl Erik.
Einar answered sadly as he dropped the pieces of his bow:  Norway from thy hands, my king!

shoot.sentence: Shoot me that tall, beardless youth!

full.sentence: Full fifty of our best men has he slain with his arrows this day!

finn.sentence: Finn Eyvindson, to whom Erik spoke, aimed an arrow at Einar just as the lad was bending his bow for a second shot at the earl.

take.sentence: Take my bow and shoot with it instead.

gathering.sentence: Gathering all his available men together he prepared to make a rush upon the Long Serpents deck.

twelve.sentence: Twelve are still left, he answered.

ben.sentence: Ben Gunn was on deck alone, and as soon as we came on board he began, with wonderful contortions, to make us a confession.

blandly.sentence: Blandly was beginning to think of fitting out her consort.

captain.sentence: Captain Smollett is now retired from the sea.

gray.sentence: Gray not only saved his money, but being suddenly smit with the desire to rise, also studied his profession, and he is now mate and part owner of a fine fullrigged ship, married besides, and the father of a family.

oxen.sentence: Oxen and wainropes would not bring me back again to that accursed island; and the worst dreams that ever I have are when I hear the surf booming about its coasts or start upright in bed with the sharp voice of Captain Flint still ringing in my ears: Pieces of eight!

was.sentence: was the cry and boats were put out to rescue him.

devil.sentence: Devil got them for sure, Massa Malone, said he.
